hints.content:
Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.

We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Let's take a look at how Greg broke apart the numbers to multiply.

options.explanation:
$54\times 26$

We can break apart $54$ into $50 + 4$ and break apart $26$ into $20+6$.

[[☃ image 1]]

We can start by multiplying $50\times 20$ , $50\times 6$, $4\times 20$ or $4\times6 $. The order does not matter since we will be adding all the products together.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\begin{align}
54&\\
\underline{{} \times 26}\end{align}\\
\text{any order}&\left\{\begin{align}
1{,}000\\
300\\
80\\
\underline{{}+24}\end{align}\right.\\
&\begin{align}
1{,}404
\end{align}
\end{array}$
options.showPrompt: Can you show me an example please?

options.alt: A rectangular array split in 4 parts. The top left part has a height of 6 and a base of 50. The top right part has a height of 6 and a base of 4. The bottom left part has a height of 20 and a base of 50. The bottom right part has a height of 20 and a base of 4. The left side of the array is labeled 6 plus 20. The bottom of the array is labeled 50 plus 4.

hints.content:
###Step $1$

$\begin{align}
\goldE{8}6&\\
\underline{{} \times \goldE{3}7}&\\
\goldE{2{,}400}&\quad \goldE{30} \times \goldE{80}\\
\end{align}$

There are $3$ tens in $37$, and there are $8$ tens in $86$.  Also,
$\goldE{30}\times\goldE{80}=\goldE{2{,}400}$, so Greg did not make a mistake in step $1$.

$\begin{align}
8\maroonE{6} \\
\underline{{}\times\maroonE{3}7} \\
{ 2{,}400}&\quad {30\times 80}\\
\maroonE{180}& \quad\maroonE{30\times 6}
 \end{align}$

Greg said the value of the $3$ in $\maroonE{3}7$ is $3\text{ ones}$, not $\maroonE{3\text{ tens}}$, so Greg made a mistake in step $2$.
Greg made a mistake in step $2$.

question.content:
Greg tried to evaluate $86\times37$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.

$\begin{array}{llrr}
&&86 \\
&&\underline{{}\times37} \\
&\goldE{\text{Step 1}}&\goldE{ 2{,}400}& \goldE{30\times 80}\\
&\maroonE{\text{Step 2}}&\maroonE{18}& \maroonE{3\times 6}\\
&\tealE{\text{Step 3}}&\tealE{560}& \tealE{7\times 80}\\
&\blueE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\blueE{42}}& \blueE{7\times6}\\
&\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{3{,}020}&
 \end{array}$

**Find Greg's mistake.**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
There are $3$ tens in $37$, and there are $8$ tens in $86$.  Also,
$\goldE{30}\times\goldE{80}=\goldE{2{,}400}$, so Greg did not make a mistake in step $1$.
There are $3$ tens, not $3$ ones, in $37$. So Greg made a mistake in step $2$.

There are $7$ ones in $37$, and there are $8$ tens in $86$.  Also,
$\tealE{7}\times\tealE{80}=\tealE{560}$, so Greg did not make a mistake in step $3$.

There are $7$ ones in $37$, and there are $6$ ones in $86$.  Also,
$\blueE{7}\times\blueE{6}=\blueE{42}$, so Greg did not make a mistake in step $4$.
Greg correctly added his four partial products.
